subject: Re: [junit] Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... I have observed the opposite: programmers consistently overcomment their code, translating the code into natural language, sometimes on a line-by-line
messageBody:
Jim Dixon wrote:

> On Fri, 19 Sep 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > > > They're like comments. Comments are not executable and cannot
> fail if
> > > > they are wrong, so they are waste.
> > >
> > > So code should never be commented?? This makes no sense.
> >
> > Comments that merely describe how the code does things is waste. The
> > code already says that. These are the comments that a vast majority of
> > programmers insist on writing, largely because someone taught them to do
> > so in school.
>
> In my experience
>
> * few programmers comment code to any degree

I have observed the opposite: programmers consistently overcomment their
code, translating the code into natural language, sometimes on a
line-by-line basis, but often on a block-by-block basis.

> * fewer comments correlate well with more bugs

Fewer comments are generally not the cause, though: fewer comments
correlate with laziness which correlates with lack of attention to
testing, which causes more bugs. I have observed heavily-commented buggy
code and sparsely-commented code with few defects. In addition to
observing both I have written both.

> * as often as not, it's faster to rewrite uncommented code than it is
> to figure out what the code "already says"
>
> If the code is doing anything complex, if it is implementing rules
> that contain domain-specific knowledge, comments are not waste --
> they are absolutely essential.

Not essential, although they can help. If the code simply said what the
comments say, then they *would* be both the comments and the logic. It's
simply a matter of choosing better names and extracting methods where
appropriate.

> > > > Diagnostic messages are not
> > > > assertions and cannot fail if they are wrong, so they are waste.
> > >
> > > It is trivially easy to put diagnostic messages inside an if -- you
> > > see them if something of interest occurs.
> >
> > Waste is waste. Large amounts of waste often build themselves up from a
> > large number of small amounts of waste.
>
> Often you work with code that is uncommented, buggy, and incomprehensible.
> One useful way to figure it out is sprinkling diagnostic messages here
> and there, running it, and watching what falls out.
>
> There are many other approaches. Some people use one, some another.
> If you are fortunate, you have a variety of people working with you, so
> that when you can't understand what's in front of you, you can pass the
> problem over to someone else with a different set of skills. If you
> are _very_ fortunate, you will have more than one tool in your own bag
> of tricks.

I'm not saying that I don't know how to write printf() or use the
debugger. I just choose not to when I can write tests instead. It's
clear to me that tests provide the same benefits as printf() *and*
preserve what I have learn for posterity. "It's no good to anyone else
in your head, Mozart. Write it down." (paraphrase of Salieri from the
film Amadeus.)
